entry.title: Comment 1
entry.content:
I've come across TOR before and liked the idea - I understand the basic principle and see how the basic concept works as a security measure. I didn't do much at the time but now I'm looking for a safe way to surf and use the Internet.

However, having read your pages, I can't make sense of what it's all about and there seem to be an awful lot of settings that mean nothing to me.

Can you explain to me, in relatively simple terms what joining TOR means, what sort of security it will afford me, am I expecting more in terms of security than it is really capable of providing and, if it is the security measure that I'm looking for, how do I go about getting it onto my computer (MAC Leopard) so that it works and I can surf and use the internet without the nosey buggers seeing what I am up to.

I'd appreciate your thoughts.

entry.title: Comment 2
entry.content: There is no "joining" per se. It's a free software program that anyone can use. You can read more about Tor at https://www.torproject.org/30seconds.html.en

entry.title: Comment 3
entry.content: Is the Tor Project working on a Portable Tor for USB keys? I have seen one on the net that packages Tor, Privoxy and Vidalia with the website having some links back to The Tor Project but I do not know if it is coming from a reliable source. I began to do an install and it did not do what the instructions said it should.

entry.title: Comment 5
entry.content:
Thanks for pointing me to the Tor bundle.

Two challenges: 1. It is in Alpha; 2. I already have Portable FF3.05. I read the install instructions and it does not appear to include a custom install option so that I can choose which components to install (ie everything but FF). If not, is there any reason why I cannot install the standalone versions of Tor and the other complementary apps on my key?

I have a lot of time invested in building my FF with add-ons and extensions and don't want to reverse everything. Unfortunately I don't have the time at the moment to be involved in testing or I would install the alpha bundle.

Also, I am using the PortableApps.com platform. Are there any plans for the TorProject to build a portable version for this platform or is that what the Tor Bundle is intended for? I will be asking the same question on the PA forum:-)

Thanks.

entry.title: Comment 6
entry.content: ya any updates for the tor browser bundle on tat link or still the same version 2.01.8.Please tell me

entry.title: Comment 7
entry.content:
OK, slap me. For whatever reason I had not searched the PA forums. There is lots of discussion about portable TOR although there is still not an official PA build. So I'd still settle for installing the standalone build from here if feasable.
Thanks...and I'll try to do my homework next time;-)

entry.title: Comment 8
entry.content:
ERROR on a SUSE 11 Desktop

Package /root/Desktop/tor-0.2.0.34-tor.0.suse.i386.rpm could not be installed.

Details:
Subprocess failed. Error: RPM failed: error: Failed dependencies:
libevent-1.4.so.2 is needed by tor-0.2.0.34-tor.0.suse.i586
regards

entry.title: Comment 9
entry.content:
The actual error there is that libevent-1.4 isn't installed, not that there isn't an i586 rpm. i386 rpms work fine in i586 systems.

You should install libevent-1.4.
